subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: among and above have
msgSnippet: Hi Robert, I used a PDF file because it includes the fonts within its structure and can be opened on almost any platform. If I load the orignal Word document,
messageBody:
Message
Hi Robert,
 
I used a PDF file because it includes the fonts within its structure and can be opened on almost any platform. If I load the orignal Word document, to read it you'd have to have the Jerome font and something that will read Word correctly.
 
I was about to send up several smaller Zipped PDF files but if you think there's a better format I'll try it.
 
 
Phonic Pronunciation Source Data

The phonic pronunciations were derived by Carnegie Mellon University. It was compiled in a machine-readable pronunciation dictionary for standard North American English that contains over 125,000 words. The dictionary uses a phoneme set of 39 phonemes, for which the vowels can carry lexical stress.

 

Carnegie Mellon University generated this dictionary using the following independent sources:

- a 20k+ general English dictionary, built by hand at Carnegie Mellon (extensively proofed and used).

- a 200k+ UCLA-proofed version of the shoup dictionary.

- a 32k subset of the Dragon dictionary.

- a 53k+ dictionary of proper names, synthesiser-generated, unproofed.

- a 200k dictionary generated with Orator, unproofed.

- a 200k dictionary generated with Mitalk, unproofed.

 

If you'd like to play around with it, check it out at: http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict . 

 

P.S. The problem with a tabbed Text format translation it that it only supports ASCI Text. There is the need to get a keyboard mapping that does not match standard Roman charaters into a font that looks like Quickscript. Unless you are using a font enabled word processor, I don't see how QS can be derived.

 

Have fun and let us know who it comes out.

 
 
Chuck
-----Original Message-----
From: robert McBroom [mailto:mcbroom1946@...]
Sent: Tuesday, August 03, 2004 6:03 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: among and above have

I'm on a Mac too, and I've NEVER been able to open
that dictionary. It is, though, possible to download
the original from the "Speech at CMU" site as a pure
text file.

I have succeeded in using Filemaker to change their
coding to the Jerome coding, and that new file is
something that I can forward as tab-text or a
Filemaker file, if you are interested. I think will
prove much more useful than a pdf that is locked in
stone, like it fell from Heaven or something.


--- oliver langan <yahoo@...> wrote:

> > This is from the dictionary that is located in the
> "Files
> >
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/>
>  > Resources" section
> > of the web site. That dictionary was build from a
> phonic database.
>
> I have tried to download that dictionary several
> times, and I just can't get the two halves to
> combine into a 'real' file.  Could you please upload
> it again as a single file, or perhaps
> explain to me how you originally unzipped it?  I am
> using a Mac (and thus have access to
> unix command-line tools also).  I'd love to play
> with it!
>
> oliver
>
>
>


=====
Bob McBroom Woodstock NY"Begin the morning by saying to yourself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happened to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil. But I  have seen the nature of the good, that it is beautiful, and of the bad, that it is ugly, and the nature of him who does wrong, that it is akin to mine, and participates in the same intelligence, and holds the same portion of divinity."- Marcus Aureliius

Hi Robert,
 
I used a PDF file because it includes the fonts within its structure and can
be opened on almost any platform. If I load the orignal Word document, to
read it you'd have to have the Jerome font and something that will read Word
correctly.
 
I was about to send up several smaller Zipped PDF files but if you think
there's a better format I'll try it.
 
  _____  

 
Phonic Pronunciation Source Data

The phonic pronunciations were derived by Carnegie Mellon University. It was
compiled in a machine-readable pronunciation dictionary for standard North
American English that contains over 125,000 words. The dictionary uses a
phoneme set of 39 phonemes, for which the vowels can carry lexical stress. 

 

Carnegie Mellon University generated this dictionary using the following
independent sources:

- a 20k+ general English dictionary, built by hand at Carnegie Mellon
(extensively proofed and used).

- a 200k+ UCLA-proofed version of the shoup dictionary.

- a 32k subset of the Dragon dictionary.

- a 53k+ dictionary of proper names, synthesiser-generated, unproofed.

- a 200k dictionary generated with Orator, unproofed.

- a 200k dictionary generated with Mitalk, unproofed.

 

If you'd like to play around with it, check it out at:
http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict .  

 

P.S. The problem with a tabbed Text format translation it that it only
supports ASCI Text. There is the need to get a keyboard mapping that does
not match standard Roman charaters into a font that looks like Quickscript.
Unless you are using a font enabled word processor, I don't see how QS can
be derived. 

 

Have fun and let us know who it comes out.

 
 
Chuck
